Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: 3-D Integrated Hybrid Energy Harvesting and Storage Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a low cost, multifunctional energy harvesting and storage device. The single device can harvest both light and RF (radio frequency) into electricity and store the energy in the same device with 3-D architecture. Due to the single substrate and simplified, low cost processes, the cost of ownership will be reduced largely. The implementation of a low cost process of inkjet printers will further reduce the cost.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project includes applications in wireless sensor network, RFIDs, industrial process monitoring, supply chain management, security, medical monitoring, remote and hazardous environment monitoring, and wearable electronics. The success of this project will enable the above applications to gain greater market acceptance, reduce energy demand from non-renewable sources, and hence help establishing the leadership of the U.S. in the area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project MicroSol Technologies has invented and developed a novel 3-D hybrid energy harvesting and storage device.  The hybrid energy harvesting and storage device converts both light and electromagnetic field energy into electricity in the same substrate and at the same time, and store electricity in the same device, which provides a more reliable and efficient way to enable electronic systems with self-powered function. Due to the integrated processing flow from the 3-D structure, we predict that the final cost will be comparable to a single energy harvesting device.   An output power of 10mW was generated with a device with the size of 2.5x5 cm2. A self-powered temperature wireless sensor node prototype and a smartphone app have been also developed using the integrated energy harvester.

With reduction in power consumption and the size of electronic system, the self-powered sensors networks have become a growing market with high potential. For applications in the remote and hazardous environments, wireless sensor nodes require a battery life time of 10-20 years, which cannot be satisfied by current commercial batteries. In addition, the battery replacement is not being practical due to cost, and in many cases, inaccessible environments. The battery disposal is an environmental concern too.  Hybrid energy harvesting and storage system allows wireless sensor networks to employ a large number of wireless sensor nodes with low maintenance and cost. 3-D integrated energy harvesting and storage system fabricated on the same substrates will solve those issues.  The broad applications include wireless sensor network, RFIDs, industrial process monitoring, supply chain management, security, medical monitoring, remote and hazardous environment monitoring, and wearable electronics. 

 


Last Modified: 03/06/2015
Modified by: Yuanning Chen
